bcl:section.bcl:text: In this regulation, Act means the Public Health Act.
The following are prescribed as health hazards:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: milk for human consumption that has not been pasteurized at a licensed dairy plant in accordance with the Milk Industry Act;
unpasteurized milk or milk products from a farm or dairy where a person is living and is suffering from or a carrier of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a communicable disease that can be spread by raw milk and must be reported under the Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pet food meat containing micro-organisms capable of producing disease in humans.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not remove, or permit to be removed, milk or milk products described in section 2 (b) from the farm or dairy without the written consent of a medical health officer, unless the milk or milk products are to be pasteurized before distribution or use.
A person must not sell, or offer for sale, pet food described in section 2 (c).

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pesticide application order means an order, made under section 5, to apply pesticides;

pesticide use authority means an authorization under the Integrated Pest Management Act for the minister, a health authority or a local government to use pesticide products for the purpose of controlling mosquito species in areas of British Columbia where there is a risk to human health from West Nile virus.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are prescribed as health hazards:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: West Nile virus;
any agent or condition that transmits, or contributes to the transmission of, West Nile virus.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The application of pesticides for the purposes of preventing or removing a health hazard prescribed under subsection (2) is prescribed as a preventive measure.

The provincial health officer or a medical health officer may order a local government to apply pesticides to any area within the jurisdiction of the local government if the provincial health officer or medical health officer is satisfied that it is necessary to protect public health through the prevention or removal of a health hazard prescribed in section 4 (2).
A person issuing a pesticide application order must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve the order on the local government,
set out in the order

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the time by which the local government must comply, and
any conditions of a pesticide use authority with which the local government must comply, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide the local government a copy of the pesticide use authority.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person issuing a pesticide application order may authorize in the order the application of pesticides to private property, with or without the consent of the owner or occupant of the property.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A local government that is served with a pesticide application order must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with the order on or before the date set out in the order,
comply with any conditions set out in the order, and
provide to the person who issued the order any information or assistance required by that person to comply with any conditions of the pesticide use authority.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: landlord, rental unit, and tenant have the same meaning as in the Residential Tenancy Act;
potable water has the same meaning as in the Drinking Water Protection Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must not rent a rental unit that is not connected to a water supply system unless the landlord can provide the tenant with a supply of potable water for domestic purposes.
Unless permitted under an enactment, a landlord must not rent a rental unit that does not have

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 11 m3 of airspace for each tenant, and
a window that may be opened by tenants of the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A rental unit that does not meet the requirements of this section is prescribed as a health hazard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Distance of wells from possible source of contamination

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who installs a well, or who controls a well installed on or after July 20, 1917, must ensure that the well is located at least

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 30 m from any probable source of contamination,
6 m from any private dwelling, and
unless contamination of the well would be impossible because of the physical conformation, 120 m from any cemetery or dumping ground.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who controls a well installed before July 20, 1917, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: remove any source of contamination within the distances set out in subsection (1), or
subject to subsection (3), decommission the well in accordance with the Groundwater Protection Regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) (b) does not apply to a well located within 6 m of a private dwelling unless it can be shown that the well should be abandoned for a reason other than proximity to a private dwelling.
A well that does not meet the requirements of this section is prescribed as a health hazard.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Nicotine and nicotine salts are prescribed as a health hazard, except for nicotine or nicotine salts that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Schedule I drugs under the Drug Schedules Regulation, or
expressly excepted as Schedule I drugs under that regulation.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Public Health Act, S.B.C. 2008, c. 28, ss. 111, 114, 123 and 126.]
